title: Change homepage url from http to https
Request logging for node master/worker app
doFilter middleware for express static content?
body:
Hi, I tried to look through the issues with the keywords "filter static" but to no avail so I'm opening a new issue. Would appreciate if anyone could guide me to the right path if I'm wrong.

Is there any way to hook a filter function to all the static content on Express v4? I would like all request to pass through a filter function (that can do some server side stuff and possibly transform the content) before returning the static content.

Here's 2 business cases for why I need this:

1. I have a dynamic stylesheet (from a previous platform) which contains special syntax for values that are derived from settings. (e.g. color: <%=globalTheme.primaryColor%>). So I will need the filter function to populate "<%=globalTheme.primaryColor%>" with "#ffff00" when user requests for the stylesheet.

2. Logging / Authentication.  E.g. for PDF files / images, I might want to log the IP, datetime of access, pdf file name when a request for the PDF file came in. A filter function will be useful in this context since the number of PDF files / images can be indefinite.

Thanks.

This will fix the red "dependencies" badge in the README.

title: views engines middlewares don't play well with arrow functions
Same File Have different ETag on from different server response with Play 1.2.10,
body:
Hi Team,
I am working on old play 1.2.10 application , where we use activator start/run to launch the web application. I have load balance server as apache and two server instance of application. I want to generate same ETag from both server. Cloud you please help me , where I can find and fix this. I am new to play and we are using java controller.
I tried to disable using  below conf parameter in application.conf, but does not works
# Disable the Etag Creation By Play Server
http.useETag=false
I need help to over-ride the Assets functionality using java. 

Assets built in Note :Etag support
The Assets controller automatically manages ETag HTTP Headers. The ETag value is generated from the digest (if sbt-digest is being used in the asset pipeline) or otherwise the resource name and the file’s last modification date. If the resource file is embedded into a file, the JAR file’s last modification date is used.

When a web browser makes a request specifying this Etag then the server can respond with 304 NotModified.

Thank you in Advance.

title: Header Forwarded (RFC 7239)
body:
Does express support the `Forwarded:` header as described in [this rfc](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7239)? I would be willing to write tests for it in a PR if it isn't supported ATM.

Examples:

```
Forwarded: proto=https
Forwarded: for=1.2.3.4;proto=http
```

"listening" callback stopped working on v8.7.0
Dispatch takes too much time
body:
**Context:**
```
  express: ~4.15.2
  node: v8.4.0
  MacOSX
```

Running in my laptop, so there is no other traffic to the page. I have a POST request which posts some data to a URL. The data is a json string which is around 1kb.

**Problem:**
Around 10% of my calls (for the exact same data) takes a lot of time to return anything. Looking at the express logs, it looks like express is taking a lot of time (like minutes) to dispatch the POST request.

```
POST /save-image-data 200 1.534 ms - 876
  express:router dispatching POST /save-image-data +6m
  express:router query  : /save-image-data +0ms
  express:router expressInit  : /save-image-data +0ms
  express:router logger  : /save-image-data +0ms
  express:router jsonParser  : /save-image-data +0ms
  express:router urlencodedParser  : /save-image-data +1ms
  express:router cookieParser  : /save-image-data +0ms
  express:router serveStatic  : /save-image-data +0ms
  express:router router  : /save-image-data +0ms
  express:router dispatching POST /save-image-data +0ms
```

I saw a previous issue https://github.com/expressjs/express/issues/2401 , but it was closed due to not enough information.

title: RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded
body:
Express v.4.15.4
Please help to find the root cause of this issue: 

```
RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded
    at next (D:\App\server\node_modules\express\lib\router\index.js:176:16)
    at Layer.handle_error (D:\App\server\node_modules\express\lib\router\layer.js:67:12)
    at trim_prefix (D:\App\server\node_modules\express\lib\router\index.js:315:13)
    at D:\App\server\node_modules\express\lib\router\index.js:284:7
    at Function.process_params (D:\App\server\node_modules\express\lib\router\index.js:335:12)
    at next (D:\App\server\node_modules\express\lib\router\index.js:275:10)
    at Layer.handle_error (D:\App\server\node_modules\express\lib\router\layer.js:67:12)
    at trim_prefix (D:\App\server\node_modules\express\lib\router\index.js:315:13)
    at D:\App\server\node_modules\express\lib\router\index.js:284:7
    at Function.process_params (D:\App\server\node_modules\express\lib\router\index.js:335:12)
    at next (D:\App\server\node_modules\express\lib\router\index.js:275:10)
    at Layer.handle_error (D:\App\server\node_modules\express\lib\router\layer.js:67:12)
    at trim_prefix (D:\App\server\node_modules\express\lib\router\index.js:315:13)
    at D:\App\server\node_modules\express\lib\router\index.js:284:7
    at Function.process_params (D:\App\server\node_modules\express\lib\router\index.js:335:12)
    at next (D:\App\server\node_modules\express\lib\router\index.js:275:10)
    at Layer.handle_error (D:\App\server\node_modules\express\lib\router\layer.js:67:12)
    at trim_prefix (D:\App\server\node_modules\express\lib\router\index.js:315:13)
    at D:\App\server\node_modules\express\lib\router\index.js:284:7
    at Function.process_params (D:\App\server\node_modules\express\lib\router\index.js:335:12)
    at next (D:\App\server\node_modules\express\lib\router\index.js:275:10)
    at Layer.handle_error (D:\App\server\node_modules\express\lib\router\layer.js:67:12)
```
It looks like a recursion in `Layer.handle_error -> next -> Function.process_params -> trim_prefix -> etc.`
I doubt if it's related to #2412 because it only happens sporadically and unfortunately it's not clear what causes it.

My hypothesis is that `Layer.handle_error` keeps [going back](https://github.com/expressjs/express/blob/c0136d8b48dd3526c58b2ad8666fb4b12b55116c/lib/router/layer.js#L71) into the failed middleware instead of moving on. 
Any ideas?

title: Possible bug in chunk transformation from 4.16.0 onwards
Express 5 router strange behavior (parameters)
TypeError in send(Buffer) when an ETag is set
body:
A recent [commit](https://github.com/expressjs/express/commit/48940e61202be07677659b3b9d87c967fc4e8bdc) introduced a condition where TypeError will be thrown when calling `res.send(Buffer)`. 

If an ETag has already been set, `generateETag` will be false, and if `chunk` is a Buffer with a length less than 1000, `Buffer.byteLength` will be used to calculate the length, but the `chunk` is a Buffer and not a string.

title: Same dispatching POST, but different route
body:
Using Node 6.4.0, Express 4.15.4

I want to know why there's a different route for the same POST.

```
express:router dispatching POST /my-app/api/initial-state?country=NL&language=en&localeStringDateTime=en&localeStringNumber=nl-NL +17ms
express:router query  : /my-app/api/initial-state?country=NL&language=en&localeStringDateTime=en&localeStringNumber=nl-NL +1ms
express:router expressInit  : /my-app/api/initial-state?country=NL&language=en&localeStringDateTime=en&localeStringNumber=nl-NL +0ms
express:router jsonParser  : /my-app/api/initial-state?country=NL&language=en&localeStringDateTime=en&localeStringNumber=nl-NL +0ms
express:router compression  : /my-app/api/initial-state?country=NL&language=en&localeStringDateTime=en&localeStringNumber=nl-NL +1ms
express:router cookieParser  : /my-app/api/initial-state?country=NL&language=en&localeStringDateTime=en&localeStringNumber=nl-NL +25ms
express:router <anonymous>  : /my-app/api/initial-state?country=NL&language=en&localeStringDateTime=en&localeStringNumber=nl-NL +0ms
express:router webpackDevMiddleware  : /my-app/api/initial-state?country=NL&language=en&localeStringDateTime=en&localeStringNumber=nl-NL +0ms
express:router <anonymous>  : /my-app/api/initial-state?country=NL&language=en&localeStringDateTime=en&localeStringNumber=nl-NL +0ms
express:router trim prefix (/my-app) from url /my-app/api/initial-state?country=NL&language=en&localeStringDateTime=en&localeStringNumber=nl-NL +0ms
express:router corsMiddleware /my-app : /my-app/api/initial-state?country=NL&language=en&localeStringDateTime=en&localeStringNumber=nl-NL +0ms
express:router trim prefix (/my-app) from url /my-app/api/initial-state?country=NL&language=en&localeStringDateTime=en&localeStringNumber=nl-NL +3ms
express:router hidePoweredBy /my-app : /my-app/api/initial-state?country=NL&language=en&localeStringDateTime=en&localeStringNumber=nl-NL +1ms
express:router trim prefix (/my-app) from url /my-app/api/initial-state?country=NL&language=en&localeStringDateTime=en&localeStringNumber=nl-NL +0ms
express:router serveStatic /my-app : /my-app/api/initial-state?country=NL&language=en&localeStringDateTime=en&localeStringNumber=nl-NL +0ms
express:router correlationIdMiddleware  : /my-app/api/initial-state?country=NL&language=en&localeStringDateTime=en&localeStringNumber=nl-NL +0ms
express:router trim prefix (/my-app/api) from url /my-app/api/initial-state?country=NL&language=en&localeStringDateTime=en&localeStringNumber=nl-NL +0ms
express:router router /my-app/api : /my-app/api/initial-state?country=NL&language=en&localeStringDateTime=en&localeStringNumber=nl-NL +0ms
express:router dispatching POST /initial-state?country=NL&language=en&localeStringDateTime=en&localeStringNumber=nl-NL +52ms
express:router nosniff  : /my-app/api/initial-state?country=NL&language=en&localeStringDateTime=en&localeStringNumber=nl-NL +1ms
express:router frameguard  : /my-app/api/initial-state?country=NL&language=en&localeStringDateTime=en&localeStringNumber=nl-NL +0ms
express:router corsMiddleware  : /my-app/api/initial-state?country=NL&language=en&localeStringDateTime=en&localeStringNumber=nl-NL +0ms
express:router <anonymous>  : /my-app/api/initial-state?country=NL&language=en&localeStringDateTime=en&localeStringNumber=nl-NL +0ms
```

as you can see the first POST is routed to `/my-app/api/initial-state`
the second to `/initial-state`
I would expect that the second is also routed to `/my-app/api/initial-state`

```js
index.js
/**
 * Registers POST method on the /initial-state endpoint.
 * @param {Object} parentRouter - The parent router of this endpoint
 */
function registerWith (parentRouter) {
  const router = express.Router()
  parentRouter.use('/initial-state', router)
  router.use(noCache)
  router.post('/', postInitialState)
}
```

Am I doing something wrong here?

title: Bump debug to 3.1.0
body:
`Regular Expression Denial of Service` Affecting `debug <= 3.1.0`.

Because of this, it prevents all the modules using express and `nsp check` to pass the security checks.

title: Warning: Express' tests break under forthcoming Mocha v4.0.0
body:
I ran express' `master` tests against Mocha's current `master` branch (via [dont-break](https://npm.im/dont-break)), and the tests did not complete (the Node.js process hangs).  

This is *likely* because of a forthcoming change in v4 which will cause Mocha to *not* force exit its own process once it's finished running tests (by default).  See [this issue](https://github.com/mochajs/mocha/issues/2879) for more background.

If I had to hazard a guess, likely one or more of Express' tests are leaving socket(s) open instead of closing them explicitly.

If Express wishes to upgrade, its options are:

1.  Audit the tests and ensure they are not leaving any sockets, servers, etc., open/listening when they complete, or
2.  Revert to pre-v4 behavior by supplying the `--exit` option to Mocha

title: Express 4.16.0 express.static broken for filename
body:
I'm opening this issue to discuss and / or talk about an issue that has been reported twice (that I know of, at the time of opening this issue) so far regarding a change of behavior in `express.static` in Express 4.16.0 release.

In Express.js 4.16.0 there is a change in `express.static` that shouldn't cause issues (assuming correct API usage) but mitigates Express.js apps from the [Node.js path validation vulnerability](https://nodejs.org/en/blog/vulnerability/september-2017-path-validation/).

After tracking it down, it turns out there may be some apps (I don't know how common / uncommon yet) that were providing a file name as the first argument of `express.static` instead of a file path. This combined with a `app.use` path that would match the entire URL (like `/*` for example) seems to have been accidentally serving that file to all URLs in prior Express.js versions.

If this change broke you app, first, we apologize; the API has never worked or been documented this way so we had no idea that this is something that worked and thus also had zero tests for this kind of combination.

The first argument for [`express.static`](http://expressjs.com/en/4x/api.html#express.static) (which is the `serve-static` module) is document as the name `root` with the following description:

> The root argument refers to the root directory from which the static assets are to be served.

I 100% understand that documentation can be terse and that working is working, so please don't take that as an excuse, just a post-mortem to the situation.

If you are in a situation where you can modify your app, the best thing you can do is use [`res.sendFile`](http://expressjs.com/en/4x/api.html#res.sendFile) in a middleware instead of `express.static` for this specific case.

For example, change
```js
app.use('/*', express.static('path/to/file.html'))
```
to
```js
app.use('/*', (req, res) => res.sendFile(path.resolve('path/to/file.html'))
```

We would like to better understand the impact of this (if any) to evaluate if there needs to be a follow up patch release to get the above use-case back to working. It's possible there could be another odd use-case that doesn't work as well, so it may be whack-a-mole, which is why using the correct APIs is definitely the best course of action.

**If you were impacted by this change, let us know here**. Even if you took the action of changing to `res.sendFile`, feel free to also let us know anyway (noting that you changed your app), which can help act as a proxy for the silent users as well for impact evaluation.

title: Statement on "mime" module NSP/Snyk advisory
body:
I am creating this post before issues start arriving on this. The security vendors have posted an advisory on the "mime" module (https://snyk.io/vuln/npm:mime:20170907 and https://nodesecurity.io/advisories/535), which will be flagged in current versions of Express.js (4.15.5 is the current version at this time).

**Express.js is not vulnerable to the issue identified in the "mime" module**

We are working to get a release of Express.js out that includes the updated module, but the patch for the module is on top of semver-minor changes to the module, so the update is part of the Express.js 4.16 release, which is targeted for Monday, Oct 2.

title: use() ignores path for websocket proxy
body:
Also see chimurai/http-proxy-middleware#204.

### Expected behavior
The following should listen for websocket requests only under `/__webpack_hmr`.
```javascript
express.use('/__webpack_hmr', proxy({ ws: true, target: 'http://...' }));
```

Websocket requests to other paths (e.g. `/socket.io`) should not be handled by the proxy.

### Actual behavior
The proxy "hijacks" all incoming websocket requests, also those to `/socket.io` (see socketio/socket.io#3062).

### Setup
Fiddle: https://github.com/ftes/socket.io-fiddle/pull/1/files

* http-proxy-middleware: 0.17.4
* server: express 4.13.4
* socket.io: 2.0.3

#### proxy middleware configuration
```javascript
proxy({ ws: true, target: 'http://localhost:4000' });
```

#### server mounting
```javascript
var app = express();

app.use('/__webpack_hmr', proxy);
app.listen(3000);
```

### Workaround
Pass path `/__webpack_hmr` as context to proxy.

```javascript
const webpackHmrProxy = proxy('/__webpack_hmr', {
  target: 'http://localhost:4000',
  ws: true,
});
app.use(webpackHmrProxy);
```

title: Question : Efficient way to serve dynamic image ?
body:
Hi,
I am trying to find an efficient way to serve an image with Express if it exists, using a generated path from query params.
Example : '/imageID/toto.jpg?quality=80' will refer to image in myDir/imageID_80.jpg

I am currently using res.sendFile to do this, and I saw on your docs it isn't the best way in production (my CPU usage is high 👎).
Instead it seems I should use the static middleware, but I can't see how I can tell it the dynamic path to the image.

(I opened a stack overflow issue as well, but I didn't have much luck with it yet. It is maybe more comprehensive : https://stackoverflow.com/questions/46324479/serve-dynamically-generated-image-or-saved-image-with-express)

Thanks

EDIT : I just saw this issue : https://github.com/expressjs/express/issues/3165
It seems to be quite similar. Correct me if I'm wrong. Is there a link to the Gitter discussion that followed that issue ?

title: Unnecessary Dependancy: utils-merge
body:
I noticed that express has quite a few dependancies (42) and started looking for ones that don't need to be there from the bottom up (Z->A). Right Away, I found utils-merge.

utils-merge is a dependancy consisting of one simple function to merge two objects.
Its functionality can be obtained with either Object.assign or even the spread operator.

It is required by: 
```
lib/router/index.js
lib/response.js
lib/middleware/query.js
lib/application.js
```

title: Release 4.16
body:
This is a tracking issue for release 4.16.

**Please keep feature requests in their own issues**

If you want to make a comment on a particular change, please make the comment in the "Files changed" tab so comments are not lost during a rebase.

List of changes for release:
- [x] Add `express.json` and `express.urlencoded` to parse bodies #2211 
- [x] Add `"json escape"` setting for `res.json` and `res.jsonp` #3268 #3269 
- [x] Add options to `res.download` #3327 #3370
- [x] Improve error message when autoloading invalid view engine #3251
- [x] Improve error messages when non-function provided as middleware #3426
- [x] Re-use options object for ETags #3314 #3313
- [x] Skip `Buffer` encoding when not generating ETag for small response
- [x] Support Node.js 8.x
- [x] Upgrade `content-type` module to 1.0.4 to bring in performance updates
- [x] Upgrade `etag` module to 1.8.1 to bring in a performance update
- [x] Upgrade `finalhandler` module to 1.1.0 to bring in a performance update and no `_header` usage
- [x] Upgrade `parseurl` module to 1.3.2 to bring in a performance update
- [x] Upgrade `proxy-addr` module to 2.0.2 to bring in a performance update
- [x] Upgrade `qs` module to 6.5.1 to bring in a performance update
- [x] Upgrade `send` module to 0.16.0 to bring in some fixes, `immutable` option, new `mime` module #3435 
- [x] Upgrade `serve-static` module to 1.13.0 to bring in `send` update and `immutable` option #3197
- [x] Upgrade `setprototypeof` to 1.1.0
- [x] Upgrade `utils-merge` to 1.0.1
- [x] Upgrade `vary` to 1.1.2 to bring in performance update #3434 
- [x] Use `safe-buffer` for improved Buffer API

**Testing this release**

If you want to try out this release, you can install it with the following commands:

``` bash
$ npm cache clean express
$ npm install expressjs/express#4.16
```

Owners/collaborators: please do not merge this PR :)

If I open simple html file with above code, its working fine. there is a workaround to this problem of using escapes but I wanted to know if express has any way to handle it in better manner. https://stackoverflow.com/questions/46266763/context-is-not-getting-passed-for-handlebars

title: Nodejs with express: API request failed after few mins
[BUG] Problem in parsing of get parameters
body:
Hi,
I found a pretty strange bug while parsing GET parameters send in the url using fetch.
I'm trying to send an array from the client to the server (using fetch as I said) and what I found out is that the array is normally parsed if it has exactly no more than 21 items. As soon as I add one more item, the array is parsed into the server as an object where the old array's indices are the new object keys, and values are the corresponding items in the passed array.
I know this sounds really weird, so I set up a repo that reproduces this, please [have a look](https://github.com/minu7/express-query-string-bug)

Thanks

title: Possible memory leak
body:
So there could be a possible memory leak on Express v4.x

We have been in constant communications with the Google App Engine team to troubleshoot our servers crashing thought to high memory usage 
and appears to be a memory leak in Express.

![memory use no load in production](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2850976/30178069-ba2641e0-93d5-11e7-9d71-2d8f239ba462.png)

Our API is served by Express 4.14.0, the screenshot aboce is an instance only receiving 6 health checks from Google every 5 seconds and within a few days, it crashes because of high memory usage.
We thought that was a problem within our base code but we decided to throw a  Hello World from Google App Engine which is using only a dependency which is Express 4.15.4 and the same result (graph below).
![hello world in app engine](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2850976/30178104-cf1822bc-93d5-11e7-8d2a-d7c16c3a677c.png)

Both instances received health checks from Google every 5 seconds to report their up time and send CPU usage, memory usage, disk usage to Stackdriver

The Google Cloud support team was able to reproduce the issue outside of the GCP with the  Hello World app and saw the heaps stack size staying consisitent but the overall process memory growing.  Since the only dependencies we were using was express we have decided to open an issue. Here is the memory graph that they had.

![Hello world memory stack graph](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2850976/30178132-e9d2ba9a-93d5-11e7-92a6-8c78143b68bd.png)

We are currently using Node v6.9.11 in our production.

title: found a mistake in function router.use()
Deprecate req.path and replace with req.pathname
body:
So currently in Express 4 (and lower) there is `req.path`, which is added by Express. This property will return the _pathname_ of the given request. There has surfaced two issues here now:

(1) The new Node.js HTTP/2 compatibility API introduces a new (currently undocumented) `req.path` property that is an alias for the `:path` puesdo-header (`req.headers[':path']`) and so the meaning of `req.path` in Express vs in the HTTP/2 compatibility layer differ (Express = pathname of `req.url` and HTTP/2 compatibility API = `:path` header, basically what `req.url` is in HTTP/1).
(2) The property itself is sort-of misnamed, similar to the `req.host` header that was deprecated already and replaced with `req.hostname` (to come back in Express 5.0 with the current meaning in `req.host`).

I am proposing that `req.path` is deprecated in Express 4 with a new `req.pathname` introduced in Express 4 and beyond to hold the existing `req.path` behavior.

title: Documentation for app.set is ambiguous
body:
I _think_ the recommended usage of `app.set` includes storing your own values in there. For instance, the examples in the docs show: `app.set('title', 'My Site');`. Yet the description for this method doesn't necessarily allow for this usage:

> Assigns setting `name` to `value`, where name is one of the properties from the app settings table.

This sentence seems to be quite explicit in that `name` must be one of the app settings values in the table that appears beneath this section, yet `title` doesn't appear in that table. This leads to ambiguity in how this method should be used.

If I'm right that this is also a general-purpose way to store values, would you be up for a PR that makes this more explicit? Consider:

> Assigns setting `name` to `value`. You may store any value that you want, but certain names have a special meaning to Express. These special names are listed in the app settings table.

If this is not the case, then the examples should probably be updated, and Express should possibly throw an Error if you set an invalid value.

Thanks for reading!

This is just an initial proposal (and a working example if Http2ServerRequest/Response) is exposed.

Cool, except when I look at the stack, `params` are undefined while `keys` is an array of my params. Pretty misleading. Then in my service, I can request these so called `keys` as `req.params`.

Just wonder why the params do not get populated here. Is this params property only for inherited params? like from `router.param`

title: Documentation for next('route') with app.use
body:
Hello,
your documentation of [app.use](https://expressjs.com/en/4x/api.html#app.use) says that `next('route')` can be used with `app.use`, however, this has no effect. Please change the docs or the behavior (I'd prefer the behavior). This is confusing [not only to me](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/14125997/difference-between-app-all-and-app-use/14126090?noredirect=1#comment77777592_14126090).

The API even uses the same sentence for `app.use`, `app.all`, `app.delete`, `app.get`, `app.METHOD`, `app.post` and `app.put`:

> You can provide multiple callback functions that behave just like middleware, except that these callbacks can invoke next('route') to bypass the remaining route callback(s). You can use this mechanism to impose pre-conditions on a route, then pass control to subsequent routes if there is no reason to proceed with the current route.

Another quote from #3133: (actual behavior)
> the next() and next('route') have no difference to app.use

If you change the docs, please specifically mention that `next('route')` doesn't work.

title: Allow for multiple parameter names in router.param()
body:
Hi,

I just found out about router.param() and immediately started using it in my code. It makes checks based on parameters so darn clean :) Really good job on the inventor of that idea!

While using it i found myself wondering with a url like: "/:year/:month/:day". How can you make a router.param(...) function that is called when exactly those 3 arguments have been provided in the url?
Perhaps it is possible, but i haven't seen a way in the documentation.

Since router.param() works on parameter names, i would suggest a feature like the following to allow for an implementation of the above to be possible in router.param().

```
router.param(['year', 'month', 'day'], (req, res, next, obj) => {
   obj.year; // contain the year value
   obj.month; // contain the month value
   obj.day; // contain the day value
});
```
I would say that the first array in which the params are provided as string must be the exact order in which they would occur in the app.get('/:year/:month/:day' ...) function;

Is there any technical (or practical) reason why a feature like this wouldn't be possible?
What are your thoughts on this?

Best regards,
Mark

title: HEAD request on 404 not closing the connection
body:
Scenario:

server.js:
```js
const express  = require('express');
const app = express();

app.get('/', (req, res, next) => {
  res.send('hello world');
});

app.listen(3000);
```
generate a 404 with a HEAD request:
```bash
$ curl -X HEAD localhost:3000/404
```
then the connection just stays open. however if you send a HEAD request with `-I` instead, the connection is closed (by curl maybe?):
```bash
$ curl -I localhost:3000/404
HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found
X-Powered-By: Express
Content-Security-Policy: default-src 'self'
X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff
Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8
Content-Length: 143
Date: Fri, 21 Jul 2017 14:38:50 GMT
Connection: keep-alive
```
shouldn't express (or finalhandler) close the connection in the case of a 404 for a HEAD request? seeing as it's the one setting the 404 header in the first place?

title: Request for request #3327, allowing res.download to supply options to res.sendFile
body:
- Added an "options" field to res.download, allowing for options to be passed into sendFile
- Options will include the existing Content-Disposition header by default, unless explicit headers are provided
- Added tests for the new res.download functionality - with blank options, with allowed dotfiles, and with a custom Content-Disposition

title: content-length header is added even when transfer-encoding: chunked is returned from backend server #832
Add linter configuration to help ensure consistency in the project codebase
body:
The [Collaborator Guide](https://github.com/expressjs/express/blob/master/Collaborator-Guide.md) states that code must follow the [JavaScript Standard Style](https://standardjs.com/). However, the codebase does not follow all of the rules consistently (especially the rule against using semicolons). In fact, there are over 10,000 Standard style violations in the codebase.

## Suggestions for making the codebase better
### 1. Make Standard compliance mandatory
1. Include Standard as a `devDependency` in the `package.yml` file so that everyone who works on the project automatically has access to the linter.
2. Update Collaborator guide with instructions on how to run the linter.
3. Run standard as part of the build process to ensure that all code follows the standard.

### 2. Use ESLint
Standard uses ESLint as its backend. If more control over style is necessary, it is easy to configure ESLint to ensure that all code is formatted according to the project's desired style guide.

title: Suggestion: Implicitly-named error handler
body:
Apologies if this has been already requested, if it has I've been unable to find it in the issues or elsewhere on this project page. If this is completely contradictory to the intended design of express and I'm an utter moron, then for that, I also profusely apologise

As per the documentation (https://expressjs.com/en/guide/error-handling.html), it's recommended or suggested practice to place error handlers after middleware to pick up any errors that get passed on. 

However, when I am working on projects containing a lot of middleware, it is a little bit of an eyesore to keep pasting in error handlers after middleware, and also some middleware doesn't properly implement errors or doesn't catch some errors, it becomes a pain (and yes, I am raising those instances with the middleware I encounter, too). 

This means that an error handler at the bottom of the middleware calls, which could be called, for want of a better phrase, a global error catcher, doesn't always work. For example, when using body-parser among other middlewares, and receiving invalid JSON, an error handler needs to be put specifically after body-parser to catch the invalid JSON.

Now, is it not possible for Express to pass back any errors it encounters iterating over middleware, back to one single function/class/whatever that the developer supplies (as a promise or whatever is desired) and cut off the chain of passing down middleware when it does that? That way, you can have all your error handling implemented in one place, and not have to copy-paste your error handler after every piece of middleware to make sure it catches the error you're looking for? 

It'd still be an option to use the iterative approach, of course, but is this not a possibility in future versions? 

Cheers,
